title: Using micro SD card in Nokia 6

thread.text:
Hey there, I just got the Nokia 6 and put a micro SD card in there to expand the storage. I chose the option to format the card as internal storage rather than external. Did I do the wrong thing? I want to put lots of music on this phone and some apps. The storage indicator shows the main storage is almost full and just a little bit of external SD storage has been used.
I've now read that this phone needs alot of stuff to be on the root storage to run properly. What do I do now? I want to keep adding more music files on here.
Thanks

When you "move" an app to the SD card, small pieces of it get moved. For each piece, there's a link left in internal storage, so if the pieces aren't a lot smaller than the links, you aren't saving anything.
But if the card is formatted as internal storage, you have no choice where apps go - all of storage, the eMMC in the phone and the SD on the card, are one big block of storage, and Android decides which goes where.
Did you do wrong? I think so. If the phone doesn't have enough internal storage for all your apps, you need a phone with more internal storage, or fewer apps. SD cards have a limited number of write cycles, and an app moved to the SD card may write to where it's stored. Also, if the card fails, your data could be gone.

thread.text:
I just bought a new Nokia 6 Android Device from Best Buy in the USA. 
Model: TA-1025
Android Version: 7.1.1
Android Security Patch Level: July 1, 2017
I click on System Update - it appears to try, then comes back with "Couldn't download". It appears to be trying to download "Update Google Security Patch 2017-08" - update size 119.0 MB
Any tips on how to handle this?

Well I as able to determine the error. The phone did not like my router. Hooking it up to my other cellphone and using it as a hotspot allowed it to update. 
My router was using OpenDNS and had "b/g protection" enabled. Getting the first update, changing from OpenDNS to Google DNS and disabling b/g protection... so I am not sure which of those 3 actually made it work... but regardless it is updating and working well now.
It is odd because aside from not getting the OS/Firmware update -- the phone was updating via Wifi (apps), surfing, etc... great. I did not put a SIM inside the phone.

We're still waiting for 7.1.2 in the UK ( TA-1033). I noticed that Google has now released the November patch for their devices as well. 
Come on HMD / Nokia get us up to date please.

thread.text:
US carriers Verizon and Sprint are still using the CDMA standard, while most of the rest of the world is GSM.
All carriers here purchase licenses for various segments of spectrum at auction from the Federal Communications Comission. 
My carrier (T-Mobile) uses bands 2 (1850-1910 Mhz) & 12 (698-716) for LTE. 
Band 12 is crucial for reception indoors, because that 700 Mhz frequency will penetrate walls.
Since the Nokia6 has a locked bootloader I cannot flash the proper rom for me to make use of the frequencies I need.
I asked because I have friends in London who are coming to the States Thursday, so I'd considered asking them to bring one over.

title: All Widgets disappear from HomeScreen and menu list after restart.

thread.text:
I have an (vanilla) Android Nougat 7.1.1 Nokia6 phone.
I had to restart the phone because of Blutooth connection problems and after restart all Home Screen widgets were gone (including Clock, Calendar, Chrome, Firefox and several others) from the HomeScreen. They also vanished from the Widgets menu list so I can't add them back.
How can I get them back and how is it possible that those Widgets disappeared from the Widgets menu too because of Bluetooth connectivity problems..!?
How can the HomeScreen and Widgets menu list be fixed without factory reset? 
Is there a way to reinstall those affected apps (Clock, Calendar,Chrome) so that all data and settings are restored from backup (that I have in my G-drive) cause I think that might make applications widgets to appear in the menu at least?

Welcome to Android Central. I've moved your thread to the Nokia 6 forum so that more people familiar with this device will be able to assist you. 
What launcher are you using on your device?

No launcher. Those Nokia 3,5,6 phones are basically running vanilla Android Nougat 7.1.1 with all the latest updates.
Also, I'm quite sure this is not phone model specific cause I've seen similar Widgets disappearance problems reported in many manufacturers phones, usually in Android Nougat, but in Marshmallow, too

I found this article from the web where the problem of "Widgets not showing up in the list" is exactly the same I'm suffering from, but fix stopping the Launcher doesn't work in my case.
The launcher in Nokia6 is probably the Launcher3 app and I forced it to stop and when it automatically restarted those widgets were still missing from my HomeScreen and from the menu list.https://yalantis.com/blog/the-dark-side

I just restarted my Nokia 6, because Tethering wasn't working and got the exact same problem. I even cleared the Launcher3 data, because that was given as one solution to this problem. This is hugely irritating, because I actively use 2way authentication widgets, Spotify widget and few others.

I managed to fix the problem. I restarted my Nokia in safe mode by holding down the volume down button during startup, then went to the app settings, chose Launcher3->storage and deleted cache. After restarting again, the widgets worked again.

Had this problem too. It also stopped me from long pressing on the home screen and couldn't long press on the app drawer. Talked to Nokia support on the phone app and the person there was clueless and couldn't even seem to understand what the problem was. They told me to individually clear the cache of every app on the phone... funny.
I ended up factory resetting but it will try your solution if it happens again.

Thanks @LordBhorak for your replys. Gotta try that Launcher3 cache cleaning, but why does it have to be done in Safe mode? Or did you try in Normal mode first and it didn't work?
Yes @batkingnz, I've had the same experience w/ Nokia Support (especially the chat ppl there). They never seem to understand even the most trivial technical issues or actually know anything about the phone hw or sw. Not once have I got useful info from them.
Maybe this is a generic problem in Android Nougat, or it is an implementation problem on that Launcher3 code that handles the Home Screen and Widgets (IDK whether it is vanilla Android code or custom Launcher by Nokia/HDM).
Cheers,
-experimancer

Thanks, did that cache cleaning also erase everything from the Home Screen (s) so that you had to setup them from the default one or did it stay intact and w the Widgets restored there too (and in the Widget Menu list)..?

Same thing yet again after turning it off while charging. Tried the safe mode trick and it didn't work. Ended up force closing the launcher (not in safe mode) and it came back ok. You will need to put all your widgets/apps back on the home screen.
Hope they fix this if and when they bring 7.1.2 update.

I did the data clear the first time, because the cache clear was greyed out. Data clear resets your home screen, but it didn't help with the problem. I was trying some other stuff with the safe mode, but noticed that the cache clear was available. Cache clear shouldn't "reset" your home screen... At least the apps that I had placed there after the data clear were still there. Widgets weren't naturally, but probably would have been, if I hadn't done the data clear.

Ok, tried that Launcher3 cache cleaning, booted to Safe Mode and clicked to Settings > Apps > Launcher3 > Storage > Clean cache, restarted and hey it worked! All the app Widgets came back to Menu List, from which I could add them back to Home Screens to those same locations they got erase because of a restart/Bluetooth issues.. 
This had to be done in Safe Mode, tried to stop Launcher3 and erase cache in Normal mode, but that did nothing.
In the end, this probably is not Nokia6 specific but all Android Nougat's suffer from it but if the Launcher3 code is Nokia/HDM custom code then how can we make them know about this issue, so that they could fix it in the next Nougat or System update. The next Android Oreo is also close to be made available to phones like Nokia and others, maybe it'll be fixed there.. 
Thanks a lot @LordBhorak and @batkingnz
Might try tweeting them about it so it's at least out there. Glad it all worked out for you. I've been playing with arrow launcher/Microsoft launcher and actually find it better for now.
Fast work HMD!! 7.1.2 is now available. Will monitor to see if the issue is fixed and update this thread if necessary.

title: [Resolved---kind of] Cannot use self service short codes

thread.text:
I am getting a "connection error or invalid MMI code" error when I use any self service short code I am on T-Mobile. I rebooted multiple times, had my phone reconnect to the network booted in safe mode. 
It was working normally for awhile, then last week it stopped. I called Tmo support and it has been escalated to a higher tier, but they can't figure it out.
I saw one site stating this is common for dual SIM phones, I have a Nokia 6 it is a dual SIM but US version of this phone, and I am only using one SIM. 
Any thoughts on what can be causing this, I get SMS and calls on Tmo normally otherwise. Thanks.

Well, someone helped me resolve this (no not Tmo, but it wasn't a Tmo issue). Seems the Nokia 6 no longer switches to HSPA+ mode in order to process the short code (USSD) which it needs to do, the workaround is to temporarily toggle the Nokia 6 to 3G, once this is done, the short codes work. I can then place it back onto 4G (LTE).
It used to work, so I am wondering if a recent Nokia update changed this. Not a big deal, I just have to toggle to 3G use the short code, then go back to 4G, a few seconds.
This person stated he had an issue with his LG, and found a setting to allow USSD over IMS in the hidden menu to resolve this so he doesn't have to toggle back and forth. I did not see this option in the hidden menu, so the 6 may not support it.

Welcome to Android Central! Moved from the Oreo forum to the Nokia 6 forum.
How's your cell reception when driving? If the reception is poor on some stretches of road, it might cause problems with the sound quality.
To copy photos from your PC to your phone, connect via USB, then swipe down the notification panel, tap the USB icon, and select MTP (it might also be called File Transfer). Then open Windows Explorer on the PC and drag/drop the photo files from the computer to the phone (preferably to the Pictures directory).

But call quality is otherwise ok if you're not on Bluetooth? Is it bad if you use a Bluetooth headset as well? If not, then it's probably an issue with the car's Bluetooth system.
Different phones can have slightly different ways of turning on MTP. But the default USB connection mode on most phones is Charge Only, so you typically have to change it manually to MTP -- and the easiest way is to tap the USB notification in the notification panel (assuming you see it there).

The key thing to do is test it out with another Bluetooth device for calls. If the sound quality is fine there, then it's the car.

title: Unread badges on calendar and email wrong

thread.text:
After setting up my Nokia 6 the unread count for calendar and especially the gmail app are showing an unread count that is incorrect. I have no unread emails but gmail is showing 99+, rebooted made sure all was unread, but it will not clear.
Does anyone know of a way to reset the badge counter? Thanks.

replies.text: I had the same problem. I solved it by opening Gmail on my computer, selecting All emails and marking them as read. It solved the problem within a few minutes. But I now have the issue on my calendar app. I can't remove it...

thread.text: Go to Settings>Apps, tap Menu>Show System, and look for an app called BadgeProvider. Select it, then clear cache/data. Now see if the problem persists.

thread.text: Another thing to try (which will wipe the homescreen clean as well) is to clear the cache/data from the launcher app. I'm not sure what Nokia calls it, though. You'll have to set up your homescreens again afterwards.

thread.text: True. My Nexus 5 has always had a touch of yellow, only noticed when compared to other devices. I guess the brain adjusts to some extent.

The Nokia 6. I am honestly not sure what to think about this phone, for a few reasons. The cost of the device jumps from 189 Euros to 229 (200 to 249 USD). For the extra you do get 32 GB of internal storage, 3 GB RAM, and a 5.5" display. However, the CPU remains at the 430, with no mention of the battery capacity. All this coupled with an extra version, the Arte Black, which adds 70 Euros to the price, and adding storage to 64 GB, and 4 GB RAM.
What I don't get is the extra SKU. Why not come up with some kind of cost/hardware compromise and only have a 3rd SKU? Also, looking at the screen image on the blog, the status bar setup is reversed on this device but set up normally on the others. Hands on with Nokia's new Android phones: the 3, 5, and 6 | Android Central
Any thoughts? I almost get the idea that this device was blueprinted at the last minute. Kind of a 'Let's get one more out there' kind of thing.
The bump to 1080p and the larger display will attract some buyers. I think the battery is a fixed 3000mAh. That ought to do the job.
I'm sure the battery will have an easy time with most users.
